newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish floods to slow economy briefly - CSS analyst.
newsitem.headline: Polish floods to slow economy briefly - CSS analyst.

text.p: An expected economic slowdown in Poland in the next few months due to floods is likely to be short-lived thanks to strong underlying growth trends, according to Tadeusz Chroscicki, chief analyst at the Centre for Strategic Studies (CSS).

In a monthly forecast for Reuters, he said the temporary slowdown would probably be quickly made up for by a boom in sectors producing construction materials, metals, chemicals, furniture and vehicles.
Floods in southern Poland have inundated more than 4,000 sq km killing at least 48 people and forcing tens of thousands out of their homes. Financial estimates of the damage are not yet available.

Chroscicki said, however, that despite a small improvement in May, the size of Poland's trade gap remained a concern and that there was likely to be additional growth of imports in the second half of the year for reconstruction after the floods.
He said that despite the government's 2.5 billion zloty borrowing in the central bank for flood relief, year-on-year inflation could still fall to 13 percent this year as planned.
NOTES: Official forex reserves are hard currencies held by the central bank while net reserves are the total amount of foreign exchange in the banking system.
